trans-unit.source: Deploy and Manage Azure Virtual Machines using Resource Manager Templates and the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows
trans-unit.target: Deploy and Manage Azure Virtual Machines using Resource Manager Templates and the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows

trans-unit.source: Easily deploy the most common set of configurations for Azure virtual machines and manage them using Resource Manager Templates and the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Easily deploy the most common set of configurations for Azure virtual machines and manage them using Resource Manager Templates and the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Deploy and Manage Virtual Machines using Azure Resource Manager Templates and the Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Deploy and Manage Virtual Machines using Azure Resource Manager Templates and the Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use Azure Resource Manager templates and Azure CLI to do the following common tasks for deploying and managing Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use Azure Resource Manager templates and Azure CLI to do the following common tasks for deploying and managing Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: For more templates you can use, see [Azure Quickstart Templates](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/) and [App Frameworks](virtual-machines-app-frameworks.md).
trans-unit.target: For more templates you can use, see [Azure Quickstart Templates](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/) and [App Frameworks](virtual-machines-app-frameworks.md).

trans-unit.target: Quick-create a Virtual Machine in Azure

trans-unit.target: Deploy a Virtual Machine in Azure from a template

trans-unit.target: Deploy a VM with virtual network and load balancer

trans-unit.target: Remove a resource group

trans-unit.target: Show the log for a resource group deployment

trans-unit.target: Display information about a Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: Getting Ready
trans-unit.target: Getting Ready

trans-unit.source: Before you can use the Azure CLI with Azure resource groups you will need to have the right Azure CLI version and a work or school ID (also called an organizational ID).
trans-unit.target: Before you can use the Azure CLI with Azure resource groups you will need to have the right Azure CLI version and a work or school ID (also called an organizational ID).

trans-unit.source: Update your Azure CLI version to 0.9.0 or later
trans-unit.target: Update your Azure CLI version to 0.9.0 or later

trans-unit.source: Type `azure --version` to see whether you have already installed version 0.9.0 or later
trans-unit.target: Type `azure --version` to see whether you have already installed version 0.9.0 or later

trans-unit.source: If your version is not 0.9.0 or later, you'll need to either [install the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli-install.md) or update using either one of the native installers or through **npm** by typing `npm update -g azure-cli`.
trans-unit.target: If your version is not 0.9.0 or later, you'll need to either [install the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli-install.md) or update using either one of the native installers or through **npm** by typing `npm update -g azure-cli`.

trans-unit.source: You can also run Azure CLI as a Docker container using the following [Docker image](https://registry.hub.docker.com/u/microsoft/azure-cli/).
trans-unit.target: You can also run Azure CLI as a Docker container using the following [Docker image](https://registry.hub.docker.com/u/microsoft/azure-cli/).

trans-unit.source: From a Docker host, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: From a Docker host, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: Set your Azure account and subscription
trans-unit.target: Set your Azure account and subscription

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have an Azure subscription but you do have an MSDN subscription, you can activate your [MSDN subscriber benefits](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have an Azure subscription but you do have an MSDN subscription, you can activate your [MSDN subscriber benefits](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).

trans-unit.source: Or you can sign up for a [free trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: Or you can sign up for a [free trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: You you will need to have a work or school account to use Azure resource management templates, if you have one you can type `azure login`, enter your username and password, and you should successfully log in.
trans-unit.target: You you will need to have a work or school account to use Azure resource management templates, if you have one you can type `azure login`, enter your username and password, and you should successfully log in.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you don't have one, you'll see an error message indicating that you need a different type of account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you don't have one, you'll see an error message indicating that you need a different type of account.

trans-unit.source: To create one from your current Azure account, see [Creating a Work or School identity in Azure Active Directory](resource-group-create-work-id-from-personal.md).
trans-unit.target: To create one from your current Azure account, see [Creating a Work or School identity in Azure Active Directory](resource-group-create-work-id-from-personal.md).

trans-unit.source: Your account may have more than one subscription.
trans-unit.target: Your account may have more than one subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can list your subscriptions by typing `azure account list`, which might look something like this:
trans-unit.target: You can list your subscriptions by typing `azure account list`, which might look something like this:

trans-unit.source: You can set the current Azure subscription by typing
trans-unit.target: You can set the current Azure subscription by typing

trans-unit.source: with the subscription name or the ID that has the resources you want to manage.
trans-unit.target: with the subscription name or the ID that has the resources you want to manage.

trans-unit.source: Switch to the Azure CLI resource group mode
trans-unit.target: Switch to the Azure CLI resource group mode

trans-unit.source: By default, the Azure CLI starts in the service management mode (**asm** mode).
trans-unit.target: By default, the Azure CLI starts in the service management mode (**asm** mode).

trans-unit.source: Type
trans-unit.target: Type

trans-unit.source: to switch to resource group mode.
trans-unit.target: to switch to resource group mode.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can switch back to the default set of commands by typing `azure config mode asm`.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can switch back to the default set of commands by typing `azure config mode asm`.

trans-unit.source: Understanding Azure Resource Templates and Resource Groups
trans-unit.target: Understanding Azure Resource Templates and Resource Groups

trans-unit.source: Most applications are built out of a combination of different resource types (such as one or more VMs and Storage accounts, a SQL database, a Virtual Network, or a content delivery network, or *CDN*).
trans-unit.target: Most applications are built out of a combination of different resource types (such as one or more VMs and Storage accounts, a SQL database, a Virtual Network, or a content delivery network, or *CDN*).

trans-unit.source: The default Azure service management API and the Azure classic portal represented these items using a service-by-service approach, which requires you to deploy and manage the individual services individually (or find other tools that do so), and not as a single logical unit of deployment.
trans-unit.target: The default Azure service management API and the Azure classic portal represented these items using a service-by-service approach, which requires you to deploy and manage the individual services individually (or find other tools that do so), and not as a single logical unit of deployment.

trans-unit.source: *Azure Resource Manager Templates* make it possible for you to deploy and manage these different resources as one logical deployment unit in a declarative fashion.
trans-unit.target: *Azure Resource Manager Templates* make it possible for you to deploy and manage these different resources as one logical deployment unit in a declarative fashion.

trans-unit.source: Instead of imperatively telling Azure what to deploy one command after another, you describe your entire deployment in a JSON file -- all of the resources and associated configuration and deployment parameters -- and tell Azure to deploy those resources as one group.
trans-unit.target: Instead of imperatively telling Azure what to deploy one command after another, you describe your entire deployment in a JSON file -- all of the resources and associated configuration and deployment parameters -- and tell Azure to deploy those resources as one group.

trans-unit.source: You can then manage the overall lifecycle of the group's resources by using Azure CLI resource management commands to:
trans-unit.target: You can then manage the overall lifecycle of the group's resources by using Azure CLI resource management commands to:

trans-unit.source: Stop, start, or delete all of the resources within the group at once.
trans-unit.target: Stop, start, or delete all of the resources within the group at once.

trans-unit.source: Apply Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) rules to lock down security permissions on them.
trans-unit.target: Apply Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) rules to lock down security permissions on them.

trans-unit.source: Audit operations.
trans-unit.target: Audit operations.

trans-unit.source: Tag resources with additional meta-data for better tracking.
trans-unit.target: Tag resources with additional meta-data for better tracking.

trans-unit.source: You can learn lots more about Azure resource groups and what they can do for you [here](../resource-group-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: You can learn lots more about Azure resource groups and what they can do for you [here](../resource-group-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: If you're interested in authoring templates, see [Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md).
trans-unit.target: If you're interested in authoring templates, see [Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md).

trans-unit.source: TASK: Quick-create a VM in Azure
trans-unit.target: TASK: Quick-create a VM in Azure

trans-unit.source: Sometimes you know what image you need, and you need a VM from that image right now and you don't care too much about the infrastructure -- maybe you have to test something on a clean VM.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes you know what image you need, and you need a VM from that image right now and you don't care too much about the infrastructure -- maybe you have to test something on a clean VM.

trans-unit.source: That's when you want to use the `azure vm quick-create` command, and pass the arguments necessary to create a VM and its infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: That's when you want to use the `azure vm quick-create` command, and pass the arguments necessary to create a VM and its infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: First, create your resource group.
trans-unit.target: First, create your resource group.

trans-unit.source: Second, you'll need an image.
trans-unit.target: Second, you'll need an image.

trans-unit.source: To find an image with the Azure CLI, see [Navigating and Selecting Azure Virtual Machine images with PowerShell and the Azure CLI](resource-groups-vm-searching.md).
trans-unit.target: To find an image with the Azure CLI, see [Navigating and Selecting Azure Virtual Machine images with PowerShell and the Azure CLI](resource-groups-vm-searching.md).

trans-unit.source: But for this quickstart, here's a short list of popular images.
trans-unit.target: But for this quickstart, here's a short list of popular images.

trans-unit.source: We'll use CoreOS's Stable image for this quick-create.
trans-unit.target: We'll use CoreOS's Stable image for this quick-create.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For the ComputeImageVersion, you can also simply supply 'latest' as the parameter in both the template langauge and in the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For the ComputeImageVersion, you can also simply supply 'latest' as the parameter in both the template langauge and in the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: This will allow you to always use the latest and patched version of the image without having to modidfy your scripts or templates.
trans-unit.target: This will allow you to always use the latest and patched version of the image without having to modidfy your scripts or templates.

trans-unit.source: This is shown below.
trans-unit.target: This is shown below.

trans-unit.source: Just create your VM by entering the `azure vm quick-create command` and being ready for the prompts.
trans-unit.target: Just create your VM by entering the `azure vm quick-create command` and being ready for the prompts.

trans-unit.source: It should look something like this.
trans-unit.target: It should look something like this.

trans-unit.source: And away you go with your new VM.
trans-unit.target: And away you go with your new VM.

trans-unit.source: TASK: Deploy a VM in Azure from a template
trans-unit.target: TASK: Deploy a VM in Azure from a template

trans-unit.source: Use the instructions in these sections to deploy a new Azure VM using a template with the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Use the instructions in these sections to deploy a new Azure VM using a template with the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: This template creates a single virtual machine in a new virtual network with a single subnet, and unlike `azure vm quick-create`, enables you to describe what you want precisely and repeat it without errors.
trans-unit.target: This template creates a single virtual machine in a new virtual network with a single subnet, and unlike `azure vm quick-create`, enables you to describe what you want precisely and repeat it without errors.

trans-unit.source: Here's what this template creates:
trans-unit.target: Here's what this template creates:

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Examine the JSON file for the template parameters
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Examine the JSON file for the template parameters

trans-unit.source: Here are the contents of the JSON file for the template.
trans-unit.target: Here are the contents of the JSON file for the template.

trans-unit.source: (The template is also located in GitHub [here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/master/101-simple-linux-vm/azuredeploy.json).)
trans-unit.target: (The template is also located in GitHub [here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/master/101-simple-linux-vm/azuredeploy.json).)

trans-unit.source: Templates are flexible, so the designer may have chosen to give you lots of parameters, or she may have chosen to offer only a few by creating a template that is more fixed.
trans-unit.target: Templates are flexible, so the designer may have chosen to give you lots of parameters, or she may have chosen to offer only a few by creating a template that is more fixed.

trans-unit.source: In order to collect the information you need to pass the template as parameters, open the template file (this topic has a template inline, below) and examine the **parameters** values.
trans-unit.target: In order to collect the information you need to pass the template as parameters, open the template file (this topic has a template inline, below) and examine the **parameters** values.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the template below will ask for:
trans-unit.target: In this case, the template below will ask for:

trans-unit.source: a unique storage account name
trans-unit.target: a unique storage account name

trans-unit.source: an admin username for the VM
trans-unit.target: an admin username for the VM

trans-unit.source: a password
trans-unit.target: a password

trans-unit.source: a domain name for the outside world to use
trans-unit.target: a domain name for the outside world to use

trans-unit.source: and will accept a Ubuntu Server version number -- but only one of a list.
trans-unit.target: and will accept a Ubuntu Server version number -- but only one of a list.

trans-unit.source: Once you decide on these values, you're ready to create a group for and deploy this template into your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Once you decide on these values, you're ready to create a group for and deploy this template into your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create the virtual machine with the template
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create the virtual machine with the template

trans-unit.source: Once you have your parameter values ready, you must create a resource group for your template deployment and then deploy the template.
trans-unit.target: Once you have your parameter values ready, you must create a resource group for your template deployment and then deploy the template.

trans-unit.source: To create the resource group, type `azure group create <group name> <location>` with the name of the group you want and the data center location into which you want to deploy.
trans-unit.target: To create the resource group, type `azure group create <group name> <location>` with the name of the group you want and the data center location into which you want to deploy.

trans-unit.source: This happens quickly:
trans-unit.target: This happens quickly:

trans-unit.source: Now to create the deployment, call `azure group deployment create` and pass:
trans-unit.target: Now to create the deployment, call `azure group deployment create` and pass:

trans-unit.source: the template file (in the case that you saved the above JSON template to a local file)
trans-unit.target: the template file (in the case that you saved the above JSON template to a local file)

trans-unit.source: a template uri (in the case that you want to point at the file in Github or some other web address)
trans-unit.target: a template uri (in the case that you want to point at the file in Github or some other web address)

trans-unit.source: the resource group into which you want to deploy
trans-unit.target: the resource group into which you want to deploy

trans-unit.source: and an optional deployment name.
trans-unit.target: and an optional deployment name.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to supply the values of parameters in the **"parameters"** section of the JSON file.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to supply the values of parameters in the **"parameters"** section of the JSON file.

trans-unit.source: When you have specified all the parameter values, your deployment will begin.
trans-unit.target: When you have specified all the parameter values, your deployment will begin.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example:

trans-unit.source: You will receive the following type of information:
trans-unit.target: You will receive the following type of information:

trans-unit.source: TASK: Create a custom VM image
trans-unit.target: TASK: Create a custom VM image

trans-unit.source: You've seen the basic usage of templates above, so now we can use similar instructions to create a custom VM from a specific .vhd file in Azure with a template using the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: You've seen the basic usage of templates above, so now we can use similar instructions to create a custom VM from a specific .vhd file in Azure with a template using the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: The difference here is that this template creates a single virtual machine from a specified virtual hard disk (VHD).
trans-unit.target: The difference here is that this template creates a single virtual machine from a specified virtual hard disk (VHD).

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Examine the JSON file for the template
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Examine the JSON file for the template

trans-unit.source: Here are the contents of the JSON file for the template that this section uses as an example, but you can always find the template itself [here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/azurermtemplates/azurermtemplates/master/101-vm-from-user-image/azuredeploy.json).
trans-unit.target: Here are the contents of the JSON file for the template that this section uses as an example, but you can always find the template itself [here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/azurermtemplates/azurermtemplates/master/101-vm-from-user-image/azuredeploy.json).

trans-unit.source: Again, you will need to find the values you want to enter for the parameters that do not have default values.
trans-unit.target: Again, you will need to find the values you want to enter for the parameters that do not have default values.

trans-unit.source: When you run the `azure group deployment create` command, the Azure CLI will prompt you to enter those values.
trans-unit.target: When you run the `azure group deployment create` command, the Azure CLI will prompt you to enter those values.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Obtain the VHD
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Obtain the VHD

trans-unit.source: Obviously, you'll need a .vhd for this.
trans-unit.target: Obviously, you'll need a .vhd for this.

trans-unit.source: You can either use one you already have in Azure, or you can upload one.
trans-unit.target: You can either use one you already have in Azure, or you can upload one.

trans-unit.source: For a Windows-based virtual machine, see [Create and upload a Windows Server VHD to Azure](virtual-machines-create-upload-vhd-windows-server.md).
trans-unit.target: For a Windows-based virtual machine, see [Create and upload a Windows Server VHD to Azure](virtual-machines-create-upload-vhd-windows-server.md).

trans-unit.source: For a Linux-based virtual machine, see [Create and upload a Linux VHD in Azure](virtual-machines-linux-create-upload-vhd.md).
trans-unit.target: For a Linux-based virtual machine, see [Create and upload a Linux VHD in Azure](virtual-machines-linux-create-upload-vhd.md).

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create the virtual machine with the template
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create the virtual machine with the template

trans-unit.source: Now you're ready to create a new virtual machine based on the .vhd.
trans-unit.target: Now you're ready to create a new virtual machine based on the .vhd.

trans-unit.source: Create a group to deploy into, using `azure group create <location>`:
trans-unit.target: Create a group to deploy into, using `azure group create <location>`:

trans-unit.source: Then create the deployment, using the `--template-uri` option to call in the template directly (or you can use the `--template-file` option to use a file that you have saved locally).
trans-unit.target: Then create the deployment, using the `--template-uri` option to call in the template directly (or you can use the `--template-file` option to use a file that you have saved locally).

trans-unit.source: Note that because the template has defaults specified, you are only prompted for a few things.
trans-unit.target: Note that because the template has defaults specified, you are only prompted for a few things.

trans-unit.source: If you deploy the template in different places, you may find some naming collisions occur with the default values (particularly the DNS name you create).
trans-unit.target: If you deploy the template in different places, you may find some naming collisions occur with the default values (particularly the DNS name you create).

trans-unit.source: Output looks something like the following:
trans-unit.target: Output looks something like the following:

trans-unit.source: TASK: Deploy a multi-VM application that uses a virtual network and an external load balancer
trans-unit.target: TASK: Deploy a multi-VM application that uses a virtual network and an external load balancer

trans-unit.source: This template allows you to create 2 Virtual Machines under a Load balancer and configure a load balancing rule on Port 80.
trans-unit.target: This template allows you to create 2 Virtual Machines under a Load balancer and configure a load balancing rule on Port 80.

trans-unit.source: This template also deploys a Storage Account, Virtual Network, Public IP address, Availability Set and Network Interfaces.
trans-unit.target: This template also deploys a Storage Account, Virtual Network, Public IP address, Availability Set and Network Interfaces.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to deploy a multi-VM application that uses a virtual network and a load balancer using a Resource Manager template in the Github template repository using Azure PowerShell commands.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to deploy a multi-VM application that uses a virtual network and a load balancer using a Resource Manager template in the Github template repository using Azure PowerShell commands.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Examine the JSON file for the template.
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Examine the JSON file for the template.

trans-unit.source: Here are the contents of the JSON file for the template.
trans-unit.target: Here are the contents of the JSON file for the template.

trans-unit.source: If you want the most recent version, it's located [here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/master/201-2-vms-loadbalancer-lbrules/azuredeploy.json).
trans-unit.target: If you want the most recent version, it's located [here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/master/201-2-vms-loadbalancer-lbrules/azuredeploy.json).

trans-unit.source: This topic uses the `--template-uri` switch to call in the template, but you can also use the `--template-file` switch to pass a local version.
trans-unit.target: This topic uses the `--template-uri` switch to call in the template, but you can also use the `--template-file` switch to pass a local version.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create the deployment with the template.
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create the deployment with the template.

trans-unit.source: Create a resource group for the template using `azure group create <location>`, and then create a deployment into that resource group using `azure group deployment create` and passing the resource group, a deployment name, and answering the prompts for parameters in the template that did not have default values.
trans-unit.target: Create a resource group for the template using `azure group create <location>`, and then create a deployment into that resource group using `azure group deployment create` and passing the resource group, a deployment name, and answering the prompts for parameters in the template that did not have default values.

trans-unit.source: Now use the `azure group deployment create` command and the `--template-uri` option to deploy the template.
trans-unit.target: Now use the `azure group deployment create` command and the `--template-uri` option to deploy the template.

trans-unit.source: Be ready with your parameter values when it prompts you, as below.
trans-unit.target: Be ready with your parameter values when it prompts you, as below.

trans-unit.source: Note that this template deploys a Windows Server image; however, it could easily be replaced by any Linux image, too.
trans-unit.target: Note that this template deploys a Windows Server image; however, it could easily be replaced by any Linux image, too.

trans-unit.source: Want to create a Docker Cluster across multiple regions?
trans-unit.target: Want to create a Docker Cluster across multiple regions?

trans-unit.source: [You can do it](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/201-discover-private-ip-dynamically/).
trans-unit.target: [You can do it](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/201-discover-private-ip-dynamically/).

trans-unit.source: TASK: Remove a resource group
trans-unit.target: TASK: Remove a resource group

trans-unit.source: Remember that you can redeploy to a resource group, but if you done with one, you delete it using `azure group delete <group name>`.
trans-unit.target: Remember that you can redeploy to a resource group, but if you done with one, you delete it using `azure group delete <group name>`.

trans-unit.source: TASK: Show the log for a resource group deployment
trans-unit.target: TASK: Show the log for a resource group deployment

trans-unit.source: This one is quite common while creating or using templates.
trans-unit.target: This one is quite common while creating or using templates.

trans-unit.source: The call to display the deployment logs for a group is `azure group log show <groupname>`, which displays quite a bit of information useful to understand why something happened -- or didn't.
trans-unit.target: The call to display the deployment logs for a group is `azure group log show <groupname>`, which displays quite a bit of information useful to understand why something happened -- or didn't.

trans-unit.source: (For more information on troubleshooting your deployments, as well as other information about issues, see [Troubleshooting Resource Group Deployments in Azure](resource-group-deploy-debug.md).)
trans-unit.target: (For more information on troubleshooting your deployments, as well as other information about issues, see [Troubleshooting Resource Group Deployments in Azure](resource-group-deploy-debug.md).)

trans-unit.source: To target specific failures, for example, you might use tools like **jq** to query things a bit more precisely, such as which individual failures you need to correct.
trans-unit.target: To target specific failures, for example, you might use tools like **jq** to query things a bit more precisely, such as which individual failures you need to correct.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses **jq** to parse a deployment log for the **lbgroup**, looking for failures
trans-unit.target: The following example uses **jq** to parse a deployment log for the **lbgroup**, looking for failures

trans-unit.source: You can discover very quickly what went wrong, fix, and retry.
trans-unit.target: You can discover very quickly what went wrong, fix, and retry.

trans-unit.source: In the following case, the template had been creating two VMs at the same time, which created a lock on the .vhd.
trans-unit.target: In the following case, the template had been creating two VMs at the same time, which created a lock on the .vhd.

trans-unit.source: (After modifying the template, the deployment succeeded quickly.)
trans-unit.target: (After modifying the template, the deployment succeeded quickly.)

trans-unit.source: TASK: Display information about a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: TASK: Display information about a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: You can see information about specific VMs in your resource group using the `azure vm show <groupname> <vmname> command`.
trans-unit.target: You can see information about specific VMs in your resource group using the `azure vm show <groupname> <vmname> command`.

trans-unit.source: You might need to list the VMs in a group, first, if you have more than one, using `azure vm list <groupname>`.
trans-unit.target: You might need to list the VMs in a group, first, if you have more than one, using `azure vm list <groupname>`.

trans-unit.source: and then, looking up myVM1:
trans-unit.target: and then, looking up myVM1:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to programmatically store and manipulate the output of your console commands, you may want to use a JSON parsing tool such as **[jq](https://github.com/stedolan/jq)**, **[jsawk](https://github.com/micha/jsawk)**, or language libraries good for the task.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to programmatically store and manipulate the output of your console commands, you may want to use a JSON parsing tool such as **[jq](https://github.com/stedolan/jq)**, **[jsawk](https://github.com/micha/jsawk)**, or language libraries good for the task.

trans-unit.source: TASK: Log on to a Linux-based virtual machine
trans-unit.target: TASK: Log on to a Linux-based virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Typically Linux machines are connected to through SSH.
trans-unit.target: Typically Linux machines are connected to through SSH.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure](virtual-machines-linux-use-ssh-key.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure](virtual-machines-linux-use-ssh-key.md).
